--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> 
> >--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> >
> >  
> >
> >>Important Notice. There currently exists a problem in the genome 
> >>crossover code that allows multiple connections to accrue 
between 
> >>    
> >>
> >
> >Why not just check during crossover whether any connection you 
are 
> >adding to the offspring genome is already there under a different 
> >number?  Crossover code has almost no effect on overall 
performance 
> >regardless of how much you optimize it.
> >  
> >
> I take the point about performance of the NEAT code. I tried 
measuring 
> the my gene comparison/compatibility code a while agoand it was 
not 
> measurable for a single generation (less then 1ms).
> 
> I was trying to kill two birds with one stone, by keeping 
innovations 
> matched throughout a population A) I think this is a better 
approach 
> then just keeping track of new innovations and B) It solves the 
problem 
> with crossover. But since it's not going to work with distributed 
NEAT 
> and also if say you load a seed population that already has 
matching 
> connections. I think I will have to do as you say - and maybe try 
and 
> maintain innovation numbers across the population as well if I can.
> 

Someone once pointed out to me that it would be possible to run NEAT 
without any global control at all by assigning random innovation 
numbers.  The chances two genes would actually get the same number 
by accident would be so low it wouldn't matter.  Of course then you 
would lose the nice ordering of genes and knowing which came first.

ken
